author: @LamarFrancis
text:
You know what‚Äôs so cool about this episode? A lot of these conversations happen online (especially TikTok), but they‚Äôre usually short form and no checking of biases or shortsightedness.

Here? No stone is going unturned ‚úäüèΩ

author: @MamiMelusine
text: Totally feel what Olay is saying about celebrities and influencers and the culture‚Ä¶on one hand I totally get the strategy of putting pressure on people to be morally courageous in speaking out but I do feel like some of it comes from a place of not just actual care about the issue and political strategy but wanting to feel better about yourself because the people you follow and support and like as artists are taking the stances  important to you‚Ä¶so you can keep liking them without guilt‚Ä¶or without fear, in a very self righteous and single narrative driven social media culture getting called out yourself.

replies.author: @jamesrudden90
replies.text: I think part of it, looking at things from outside the US, where a huge amount of this commentary has come from (regarding the push for celebs and influencers to be involved and make statements) has to do with how politicised every aspect of life is. I think these social media movements reflect how celebrated American politicians are, and how involved they are in controlling every aspect of life, right down to what hair is and is not appropriate. I think you hit it on the head with the result of this being a faux sense of morality and righteousness that doesn‚Äôt actually interrogate and build momentum for actual change, but nonetheless requires those performative actions like posting on social media.

author: @Ttttrp2
text: As a white man dating a black women for the past 7 years. The conflict when discussing politics, especially race, is so underplayed in media and in general. In my experience, the first year together we had pretty tough conversations that made us feel divided. I was only a teenager then, so as I cared more about politics I radically changed my views. The thing is, these tik tok trends get so much attention because the WM and BW dynamic is taboo to many and virtue signals racial "progress" without actually talking about racial politics and struggle. I definetly believe that the WM and BW couple just isn't possible without immense work both as a couple and more importantly as an individual. Also, loved the video you guys do not miss!

replies.author: @TreniaP
replies.text: There's also a big nod to class in those videos, and I think that's a big part of what people gravitate towards in that content.

author: @lowtech42
text:
The main thing I wanna say in response is for all the compassion that Khadija and Olay expressed towards Black men generally, I want to send right back to Black nonbinary people and Black women in general too but also to the two of y'all specifically. On a personal note, y'all two have foundationally shaped my understanding of the fundamental nature of the political world which has been so radical that it has pushed me past radicalism, to the precursor to the root itself, the very essence of life: universal love. And compassion is but a true act of love. So love y'all!

But on a broader note, Herby made an incredibly insightful point that people who haven't been given the space to be progressive end up regressive. It's just like plants having bundled roots once they've outgrown the pot they're in. So too do these oppressive systems constrain the humanity of ALL of us in different ways. The difference between the oppressor and the oppressed is often the latter is more acutely aware of their suffering relating to the other. No one can inflict suffering on another without incurring it within themselves. Nietzsche said as one stares into the abyss, the abyss stares back into you. Herby's observation just crystallized for me beyond the bounds of our egos, that were all just organic vessels channeling whatever greater forces are programming us. None of us fell from coconut trees‚Äîwe exist within the context of every causal event that preceded this very moment. And we're all existing within the contexts of various overarching systems that condition us into negative, harmful power dynamics based on identity. However what has been learned can be unlearned if one feels like it.

Which is why I want to tell Herby also that I love him too. I see all the pain that has informed his feelings and I want to express compassion for the suffering he's endured. I've typed so many words already and it's not even scratching a molecule on the tip of the iceberg of why Love, Compassion, and Wisdom are truly the ONLY way forward. As someone who used to think I could fight back the hate of oppression with my own righteous hate, years and years of not moving the needle has shown me otherwise. One compassionate act has done more for me than years of denigrating another through hate and/or ignorance. Everyone deserves that, especially once you realize that the pain one inflicts on others is a condition of the pain they've endured and haven't healed from. Hurt people hurt people. But Love and Compassion heals all. I love all y'all üíú

author: @beatrixxkiddo3572
text: I don‚Äôt think anyone expected Beyonc√© to advocate for political issues until she put on a black panther outfit and sat atop of a police car. Beyonc√© shouldn‚Äôt speak on political issues true but she ALSO shouldn‚Äôt capitalize off of trending issues. It‚Äôs cheap the way she uses REAL issues for aesthetic purposes only. I hated it immediately, Formation had nothing to do with the visuals she chose to include.

replies.author: @queenblacc4579
replies.text: I hear you. But also as it was pointed out why does she have to speak against EVERY political issue? Beyonc√© is a black American woman who was addressing issues that black Americans were facing in real time. Issues that she was likely informed of, that her and the people in her life likely experienced. Every activist doesn‚Äôt take up every cause. And her not speaking up on every hot button issue happening in the world doesn‚Äôt make her other actions disingenuous.

replies.text: She did make a stance on feminism & misogynoir before Formation, & feminism is inherently political. But I do understand your point and agree

People want celebrities to be a protected class because it makes them easier to celebrate. Like they alluded to in the vid, they just want to like the artist without being attached to the artist personal beliefs. My question is why do we have to stop people from wanting better from celebrities? You can listen to Beyonc√© without making the point that she should not be held to an account. Trying to give her cover only benefits her, and your ability to enjoy her guilt free.

replies.text: This is my thing! Beyonce's fans forget all of their politics , morals, and standards when it comes to her. For me, the lenses came off with her Black is King album and the Tiffany blood diamond. As an African, it felt like a cheap cosplay, and all the African Americans lambasting us and insisting that we should feel grateful didn't help. As I grew more politically active, the Black Panther thing did get more of a side eye for me, but the most recent thing for me was Break My Soul was being blasted by Israelis while they watched bombs going off in Gaza. Beyonce is quite literally one of the only celebs who could say anything without ANY REAL CONSEQUENCES, yet she remained silent. When ppl use YOUR MUSIC as the anthem for genocide, I'm sorry, but that makes it your business.

author: @gavinmccabe2908
text:
Khadija mentioned Sinead O' Connor, who is from my country and lived in my home town for the final years of her short life. Sadly, we've lost Sinead now. And her passing was really felt deeply across the country. The f'd up thing is that, when Sinead was alive and committed to her activism, she was widely attacked in both America and at home, but when she passed suddenly the internet was set on fire with notes of how we had lost a true artist, a hero. Suddenly everyone  was writing think pieces and praising her bravery and claiming her as an exemplary, Irish feminist and anti-establishment icon. 

It was, quite frankly, stomach churning.  Sinead was completely blackballed for her activism when she was alive. When she suffered with extreme mental health issues, she was ridiculed. It got to the point where she was more or less exiled from the world of fame, even though she was still producing great work. She suffered greatly because of her activism and outspokenness. It was a true reflection of who she was. It wasn't performative. She pretty much sacrificed her career for it. That's not to say that every celebrity has an obligation to do this, but it possibly does explain why people get pissed off when performers treat activism as a jacket to put on and take off, rarely risking anything. To stand up when it's safe to do so and then say nothing when things are truly at stake means you should possibly just stick to performing and leave politics out of it.

replies.author: @RheaLady
replies.text: I sympathize so much with what you're saying. The same thing happened with Muhammad Ali. I hated7and still hate listening to certain people who call him "the greatest athlete" and "so brave" without acknowledging how okay they were with him taking his losses. They were okay with his history of being punished for speaking the truth and were no willing to go further and say he was right or that we should continue to have the conversation he was trying to have.

replies.author: @gavinmccabe2908
replies.text: @RheaLady Absolutely. Another American figure, Paul Robeson, was persecuted for his relentless activism during his lifetime. It kind of wrecked his career later in  life. He was truly committed to what he was saying, though he may not have got it right all the time, he was brave in the face of constant criticism and stood for global solidarity. He said himself 'The artist must elect to fight for freedom or for slavery' There was no middle ground.

author: @Likeicare96
text:
The man vs bear convo really was what I needed. I get why women chose bear, I‚Äôm a woman who lives in our world. 

However, anyone who tried to have a somewhat nuanced conversation that was even a bit sympathetic to men (especially men who are actively trying to grow) was getting cooked. One guy, notwildin was being attacked for not understanding women‚Äôs struggles & I was so confused because I found is take very well (good balance of acknowledge why women feel this way but also how it feels as a BM to be seen as a predator). I was so annoyed because now I‚Äôm like how do we expect change to happen when we don‚Äôt leave room for people to grow?

author: @mochalily3735
text:
I‚Äôm so glad Khadija spoke on that whole ‚Äúpro-deception‚Äù thing. My biggest pet peeve about the disclosure conversation is how some people act like there is no nuance to it and you are automatically problematic for saying you SHOULD disclose to your partner. 

I am 1000% in support of NOT disclosing on the first date. You should never disclose until you feel SAFE with that person, even if it takes months of dating‚Ä¶ (although if it takes months for you to feel safe about being honest with your partner, that‚Äôs concerning and a reevaluation of the relationship might be warranted).

But disclosure before you are sexually active with that person is IMO, the safest and the most consensual way to move forward. Informed consent is a thing that always gets ignored in this. If I consent to having sex with you before you disclose all relevant information, KNOWING that the information might lead me to making a different decision‚Ä¶ then is that consent?
The unfortunate fact of the matter is, it‚Äôs risky to disclose AND it‚Äôs risky to not disclose. Trans people are being unalived and assaulted for both. 
I get that trans people shouldn‚Äôt have to disclose that they‚Äôre trans. CisHet people don‚Äôt have to disclose that they‚Äôre CisHet so why should trans? But until we get to that point where change happens, safety and survival has to be the top priority. Non-disclosure/deception/whatever you want to call it is not safe. 
Black parents don‚Äôt want to have to warn their children about the dangers of the police. They shouldn‚Äôt have to! The police shouldn‚Äôt be a risk to our lives but they are. And until we get to a point where change happens, safety and survival has to be the top priority.

author: @CatrinaTrim
text: First of LOVING the panel line up for this one fr!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è now to touch on the DL topic a little, I‚Äôm kind of in the middle between khadija and herby. While yes you should be open to people who you are trying to develop relationships with.I also think that you don‚Äôt necessarily have to be explicitly open with your sexuality stance if your partner isn‚Äôt directly asking. I know people be good a lying fr and I do feel bad for the women who get deceived by DL men. It makes me wonder how many of these women even asked what that man‚Äôs sexuality even is. For me personally as a Bi women I‚Äôm always quick to ask about someone‚Äôs sexuality because I want to make sure their fine with my personal sexuality and vice versa. That doesn‚Äôt mean that even if you ask people will automatically feel comfortable enough to tell you the truth, which is why I‚Äôm kinda on the fence. I just feel like if your a women in 2024 and you only want to date straight cis men then start asking these men what their sexuality is directly (respectfully of course). Especially living in ATL with all the queer people here there‚Äôs a lot women who will have DL stories and I‚Äôm like, you‚Äôre valid in your emotional response but like girl they might have told if you put the question out there (most of the stories I‚Äôve personally heard they never say that he said himself they were a straight man). It‚Äôs really a slight bit on you for assuming anyone‚Äôs sexuality or gender based on just what you momentarily see especially new people in your life. Hopefully my comments not to long and makes sense üòÖ.

As a community organizer by trade I think this plays into purity politics that doesn‚Äôt sever us. I think the small things that every day average folks do can be so powerful and should be encouraged and I think that applies to celebrities as well. Thanks for your content and work y‚Äôall do!

author: @jorieshouse
text: @1:12:41 This might be addressed next in the video. But I had to drop this comment real quick: a lot of these women are in fact, black women who have not been pursued by black men. I know this because I was very close I'm my late teen early 20s to adopting the mindset that draws in Divesters. Fortunately, I had an older Sister to come and collect me real quick: But not every black woman has experienced being pursued (much less pursued in a positive and respectful way) by black men.  And it's easy in that feeling of abandonment and isolation and those experiences of active rejection from black men to let that positively frame relatively neutral interactions with white men, if there's no one in a woman's life there to bring a sense of reason and critical thinking.

replies.author: @theshunnedBandersnatch

author: @JosephKerr27
text:
I think the critiques of Eminem are warranted. He's a talented wordsmith, but he's always been problematic. The "shot at a feat" line was clever, but he has too many puns that reinforce bad stereotypes and feel like punching down. There are much worse lines, too, so I'm surprised that's the one getting the most attention, but I'm glad Megan Thee Stallion is being supported. She deserves acclaim and I'm sick of the shit against her. Of course, dinosaur views are symptomatic of a lot of lingering issues in hip hop.

I like Eminem because I'm a fan of dark and irreverent humor (shocker coming from someone with a JoeKerr profile, I know), but there's a point when we have to be honest about the source of certain jokes. It's also worth mentioning that some of Eminem's best work comes when he drops the persona, i.e. "When I'm Gone". I'd like to hear more introspective stuff like that from an older Em. FD has it right when he says he dropped the ball by not taking the chance to air out dirty laundry from his past and grow into an older wiser MC.

author: @mikailagray
text: I‚Äôve always been the ‚Äúradical lefty‚Äù of my family. Since childhood I was seen as having unrealistic or too far fetched ideas about the world. Now I am happy that my sister and my mother are more engaged with these conversations especially with the intersectionality of oppression. The fact that my mom now will initiate a convo about the latest on the Palestinian genocide or my sister realizing just how connected various forms it oppression are. It makes me happy but I also have to reel my sister in because she can be a bit finger pointy  (she‚Äôs and Aries, I‚Äôm a Libra) and I encourage her to center the people at the top and give grace and or space to other if they are normies.

author: @kilgore_trout_37
text: Good morning friends

author: @ookamiblade6318
text: As someone who's family majority is interracial couples the only one who didn‚Äôt have a romance novel worthy relationship was my great Aunt (black) who married a ‚Äòwhite‚Äô dude. The ‚Äòwhite‚Äô is in quotes because he wasn't considered ‚Äòwhite‚Äô at the time of their marriage (likely how they bipassed Loving vs State of Virginia not be g passed yet), but he could always pass for white and would be considered white now. He didn't quite divorce his second wife before having a wedding with my great aunt and we only found out when trying to apply for widow survivorship benefits for his military career.

author: @the_deep_velvet
text: The thing about Beyonc√©, like do we assume that every person that quotes Malcolm X is a leftist/radical thought leader? No. So why do we assume that of Beyonc√©? People want their consumption habits to be a stand in for actual action, they want their pacification to be ‚Äúradical‚Äù. So if they can bully Beyonc√© (or other artists, corporations, makeup brands, whatever) into aligning with them then they can feel like they‚Äôre being an activist every time they listen to the albums or buy the lipstick.

author: @analogynature
text: I really love this show. Although, I wish the guests would be given more space to speak. The range of perspectives makes this show so compelling and I feel sometimes certain guests are iced out from providing necessary input.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Thank you so much. People talk as much as they want to‚Äîsome folk genuinely and naturally want to and choose to sit back and talk less. It‚Äôs a natural conversation between friends not an academic formal panel where the baton is passed.

replies.author: @LanerGuy
replies.text:
I absolutely loved this lineup here! It was wonderful, fun, funny, and all around super insightful and impactful. I think this is the first one where I knew almost everyone here from previous videos and channels I've watched and been to.

With that said, I do agree with @analogynature8757. Having followed through the video's entirety and taken mental stock of who was speaking and when ('cause I was really invested in this one), I could tell that both Foreign Man in a Foreign Land and Quei did not participate in equivocal measure to the other four participants, particularly Olay. 

Foreign really only had one, maybe two, moments where the scene focused on him and what he was saying directly. Quei had a few more of those near the latter half of the video, but her moments were a lot briefer than others' were, when she did get them. Foreign did mention elsewhere in this comment section that he actively stayed quiet out of respect for not wanting to talk over any of his fellow participants who were queer and/or fem. For Quei, I could tell that she had wanted to speak and interject a number of times, ending up ultimately opting out of doing so in most of those instances. 

This is kind of tricky to address, because I did notice that Olay was the one who did the most speaking and interjecting during this video. What makes this tricky is because this _is_ Olay's channel; she is the host, after all, the very reason everyone is here in the first place. And even more pertinent, so much of what Olay did speak to was super insightful and awesome to hear. Still, though, I do believe that in a number of the instances that Quei and Foreign wanted to speak, they could not, due in more than an occasional instance because Olay had the floor and held it longer than either Foreign or Quei had the chance to. From a viewing perspective, there was a sense of awkwardness when this occurred, as well as when taking in the video on the whole and realizing that both Quei and Foreign really did not participate relative to everyone else, in fair part due to Olay's presence being the most active.

In the end, I do hope this doesn't come off the wrong way. I just feel this is something important enough to bring up and be mindful and conscientious of so that future Olay and Friends videos ideally won't have the aforementioned instances that this one did.

author: @VettieSincere
text: I feel like our community has a huge problem putting way too much emphasis & power on figures in the entertainment industry and not enough on the social & political activists that are actually meant to spark change. I understand the concept of wanting these people to use their large platform but putting that much trust in a person who is unequipped to speak on such nuanced topics is exactly how we get a sexy redd spewing ignorant non sense. The whole thing is backwards.

author: @sarabear3
text: As far as disclosing, if you're keeping something for self-preservation, I don't think it's deceitful. But if you're willing to date someone, you shouldn't be worried about preserving yourself that way. So I get when people don't disclose initially when they are dating, but if you're going to commit, I would hope you'd know how those people would think about those things.

author: @4u2cre8
text: I 100% agree that the romanticization of exclusively dating white is disgusting. That being said, I take issue with this notion that the blame for black women's problematic perspectives towards black men is placed solely on black women, whereas black men's problematic behavior towards black women is immediately diverted by saying "Oh well that's because of the white patriarchal system". The brunt of personal responsibility for cultivating and maintaining black love seems to always land on black women while "the patriarchy" is used as a scapegoat to avoid addressing behavior by black men that push those women to consider divestment in the 1st place.

replies.author: @gabrielmeth4844
replies.text: Plantation Politics was created by white Hegemonic Structure, and we have a wealth of writing from the 19th century and after about anti-black sentiment among black people. 'Ain't I A Woman?' is a perfect example of the kind of anti-black idea very popular even today.

replies.author: @Lala_3304
replies.text: @4u2cre8 I was looking for this comment. I had a really hard time watching the video in full bc of this. I appreciate some of the pushback on this point Olay got, but I really was bothered. Even some of the most progressive people have internalized misogyny. We all have it. It just sucks

author: @winevnova
text: Damn, where was this Quei personality in the Lavern Cox episode? I wanted to hear more from her in this one. Also, aspects of these two conversations work so well together. I think the conversation regarding the bi guy that Olay dated not disclosing that information when they were in a relationship, and Herbie's response that no one owes you that information is funny looking back, because *motions to the Lavern Cox situation* That's why.(I think it's much more nuanced than that, but that part of the conversation intersects well with the response to Laverne.)

author: @AudraReinsOfficial
text: I'm going to say this from my personal experience and obviously it's anecdotal: the same way there are white women who are undesirable to white men because they don't fit a specific standard of beauty for whiteness, is the same for white men who are not desirable to white women. However, a BIG difference, is that when a white man is with a black woman, he becomes MORE desirable to the same group of white women that previously wouldn't look twice at him.

author: @cuteiswhatIaimfor
text: I‚Äôve date black men. I‚Äôve dated white men. I can‚Äôt say those experiences were vastly different. Elevating any man based on race is going to lead to inevitable disappointment. A good man who understands you and treats you well is not dependent on race.

author: @funde19
text: @KhadijaMbowe your videos about empathy between all genders have helped me a lot to learn the difference between men and patriarchy. And to communicate those ideas to other people. I'm sorry all you've been hearing is men who feel attacked and women who feel ignored. I'm a genderless critter in the wild. Your work has opened my mind. Thank you.

Leave that to the social workers and activists. We should not be guilt tripped to protest or stand for anything when we all barely have pots to piss in, and if we do it‚Äôs nothing near to Beyonc√© or her reach.
